final_poem:
# The Stillness

Not the end but the beginning — that quiet
where words are not necessary and neither are
the shadows they carry on their shoulders.
This is the kind of space where hands
can touch without meaning, where the breath
moves through the body's temple almost
as an accident. Not emptiness,
but the kitchen before anyone arrives,
the light incoming but not yet
a subject for anybody's picture.

A dog turns in the hallway and the floor
accepts her — that soft landing, that
agreement between four bones and wooden planks.
Silence does not ask to be invited.
It is the third rail beneath the conversation
that keeps heating up, the thing
the thermostat never registers.

I have spent whole afternoons sitting
in a field doing nothing — not meditating,
not waiting for anything — just
the weight of grass on my legs and the fact
that no sound was too small to matter.
A beetle's legs against a leaf. The rust
of distant metal learning its own song.
All of it kept inside its own speed.

There is a difference between being quiet
and belonging to the sound you make
when you finally stop talking.
The latter is more like an animal,
the former a room you can hear the door in.

I carry silence the way I carry
a coat I've outgrown — loosely,
not because it's empty but because
there's nowhere else I need to hold it.
